newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish PM, deputy meet in Islamist row.
newsitem.headline: Turkish PM, deputy meet in Islamist row.

text.p: Turkey's Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan met his coalition partner Tansu Ciller on Friday afternoon amid a row over religious activism that has threatened the future of the government.
The pair met at 3.40 p.m. (1240 GMT) at the prime minister's office. They made no comments as they entered the meeting.

Before meeting Ciller, Erbakan held talks with the General Secretary of the National Security Council (MGK). The powerful government-military body ordered a crackdown against Islamist zeal in a meeting in February, raising Islamist-secularist tension and sparked speculation of a government collapse.
Deputy Prime Minister Ciller earlier denied a press report that she would pull her True Path Party (DYP) out of the alliance with Erbakan.

The Yeni Yuzyil daily quoted unnamed cabinet ministers as saying Ciller, also the foreign minister, planned to withdraw the DYP from the 10-month-old government over a growing dispute between the Islamists and the army.

Members of Ciller's conservative wing are concerned at the failure of Erbakan, the country's first Islamist leader, to implement the army demands. Erbakan will face the generals at a meeting of the National Security Council on Saturday that has been billed as a showdown.
